args:
The prince and his friends finally arrive at the
top of the Sacred Tree, where they hear the
story of the world's creation and learn why
Nedrick plans to forge a pact with Bahamut.
But then the Holywyrm arrives, intent upon
preventing the pact by any means necessary.
Sure looks over to me. Now surrender and\nlet us pass while I'm still feeling nice.
...Don't you dare talk down to me.\nI told you, this is not—
This is not worth losing your life over.\nIf they wish to come to me, let them.
I am. If they learn the truth and still want\nto stop me, I'll deal with them.
I'll be waiting at the summit. If you would\nhear the truth of the world, come to me.
Help us understand, Nedrick. What are you\ntrying to do? Why do you want to use the\nDawnshard to make a pact with Bahamut?
You gave your word, Nedrick. You swore\nyou would tell my brother the truth.
But even if I tell you the truth, you may\ncontinue to doubt me.
How convenient. Are you now inventing\nexcuses not to tell us?
It merely means you are more likely to\nbelieve the truth if it comes from another\nsource. Behold...
I shall speak, if you desire it.

I have protected the Dawnshards from time
beyond creation. I convey the tale of the
beginning. Over the long eras, I came to
be known as the Sacred Tree.
Then you are the will of this tree?

If that is how you wish to think of it.
I am that which exists with the world,
and that which shall one day disappear
along with it.
Now please tell these people about the\ncreation of the world.
I shall speak of an age older than\ncounting; an age when the world\nwas not yet a world.
In the beginning—in the chaos devoid\nof heaven and earth, light and dark—\ntwo beings came into the world.
The Progenitor, known also as the human\nof beginning, and the Origin, known also\nas the dragon of beginning.
The world was forged by these two pillars\nof creation. They gave rise to heaven and\nearth, human and dragon.
All of the multitudes that now exist were\ncreated by their hand.
Quite the grand tale—but how does it\npertain to Nedrick's goal?
The tale is not over, my impatient friend.\nIn fact, it has only just begun.
The two who forged the world soon began\nto fight amongst themselves over how best\nto manage their creation.
That must have been a thing to see...
The Origin thought the world should be\nfilled with infinite possibility.
This wyrm treasured the idea of an\nexistence determined by the decisions of\nthe creatures who resided within it.
But the Progenitor sought a world of\nclear and perfect order.

It sought to manage all life in a way that
would shape the world as a single, perfect
whole—a place devoid of any unforeseen
deviation or branching.
I'm not sure I'm following all of this...
So our world that exists now is the one\nthe Origin wanted?
...I believe so. The world I once occupied\nfollowed a different course of history than\nthis one.
This world is different. It has diverged from\nmy own on the basis of its possibility.
The world the Progenitor sought is one\nwhere all things are predetermined.

How you are born? What you do in life?
When you die? All of these things are set
out before a person comes into existence.
It is a world utterly devoid of choice.
As a member of management, I can see\nthe upside in such an arrangement.
If the pieces on a chessboard begin to\nmove of their own accord, it is impossible\nto plan a coherent strategy.
Yeah, but not having any choice about\nthings at all would totally suck!
So as a result of the Origin, we live in a\nworld where possibility still exists.
Are we then safe to assume this being\nemerged as the victor in their struggle?
The conflict between these two creators\nended with neither standing.

The Progenitor was sealed away in the
otherworld, and the Origin's body was lost.
Thus did they both lose their power to
intervene in the world.
And thus was the world entrusted to the\nvery beings they had created.
So that was the beginning of everything...
It took place uncountable eons ago—\nmillions of years before Ilia was even\na glimmer in this world's eye.
And how does your objective tie into\nsomething that happened so far beyond\nthe mists of the past?
Though sealed away by the Origin,\nthe Progenitor has been regaining its\ninfluence over the long years.
I refer to many things, one of which is the\nsubstance you know as black mana.
The vile substance that fills the space\nbetween worlds is the overwhelming \npower of the Progenitor given form.
The Progenitor has spent a great deal of\ntime trying to break free from its seal,\nand now he has nearly succeeded.
If you seek proof, look how black mana\nhas proliferated over these last few years.
When the Progenitor finally breaks free of\nits seal, it will transform this world into\nthe perfect whole it originally sought.
A world where all possibility is negated,\nall choice disallowed.

Is to stop the return of the Progenitor.
Or rather, to destroy the Progenitor once
it returns, thereby cutting out the very
heart of the problem.
A bold plan. But can you explain what you\nintend to do in more concrete terms?
I will obtain the power of the Origin so I\nmight oppose the Progenitor.
In other words, I will obtain the power of\nBahamut, the Wyrm of Genesis.
It is not only the Progenitor who wishes\nto regain its influence upon the world.
The Origin—Bahamut—also wishes this,\nand has chosen me for his pawn.
When I was an infant teetering on the\nbrink of death due to wyrmscale,\nBahamut came to me.
Yes. But in the end, the pact was a failure.\nI lacked the ability to shapeshift, and\nBahamut could not regain his power.
If I wish to oppose the Progenitor, we must\nreforge our pact—and do it correctly.
I didn't know it was possible to reforge\na failed pact.
The Dawnshard has power enough to\nchange the very past itself.
Oh that's right...\nIt's why Zena's here...
If the Progenitor is freed, this world will\nbecome a place devoid of possibility.\nThis cannot be allowed to happen.
And the only way to stop it is for Bahamut\nand myself to make our pact anew.
I seek to protect the very notion of\npossibility in this world.
If all that is true, your aims seem noble.
I have spent a good deal of time with this\nman. Say what you will about him, but he\nis not one to spew petty falsehoods.
High praise indeed. I thought you might\nloathe the fellow, considering all the\nanguish he put you through.
Make no mistake—he has done things I\nconsider unforgivable. But that is a\nseparate matter from this.
Nedrick, I seem to recall Finlorda saying\nthat forging a pact with Bahamut would\npose a danger to you.
My own health is a trivial matter when\nlaid against the extinction of all agency.
...All right. For now, let's trust Nedrick.
Are you sure that is wise?
Finlorda won't be happy about it, but it's\nclear Nedrick won't be deterred.
And so far, I don't see a reason we should\nstop him.
Now THIS is unexpected! Mind you, there's\nno telling when he might change his mind\nand turn against us.
But it means that we don't have to waste\nour time on a meaningless fight.
I would have the Dawnshard from you,\nO Sacred Tree. I would have it for the sake\nof the world!
No. I will not allow it.
I will not allow the Dawnshard to fall\ninto the hands of human whelps.
Stop, Elysium! We don't want to fight you!
I have no further words to bandy with\ninsects, for I have expended them all\nacross a multitude of worlds.
It seems the time for talk has passed.
Steel yourselves, everyone! Fight for your\nlives, lest you surrender them!
